title: Mum has no memory of being pregnant or giving birth after she was hit by cruel brain condition

A mum has no memory of being pregnant or giving birth after she was struck by a devastating brain condition. 
Tina Tappenden, now 23, couldn’t wait to hold her baby when she found out she was going to become a mother for the first time. 
But Tina fell ill with a mystery condition just ten weeks into pregnancy - and spent the next six months in a total memory blackout. 
After intially being misdiagnosed with mental illness, she was eventually diagnosed with debilitating neurological condition, encephalitis - caused by the spread of an infection or virus, the potentially fatal condition triggers sudden inflammation in the brain. 
With symptoms often mirroring psychosis, the support worker was initially detained under the Mental Health Act after her behaviour became manic ten weeks into her pregnancy during a Saturday afternoon watching her nephew play football. 
Tina had been enjoying the match with her sister, when she began screaming at the referee before running onto the pitch mid-game. 
The infection in Tina’s brain caused her erratic behaviour, and saw her leave the match, sprinting into the middle of a nearby dual carriageway, totally unaware of her surroundings. 
Tina, from Canterbury, Kent, began noticing her memory loss in September 2015 and recalls one occasion when she found herself at home, but had no memory of how she got there. 
She said: “I had just driven 16 miles from work, but I couldn’t remember getting home or what way I had driven. My sister Stacey assured me it was baby brain.” Tina was in a coma at once point as the encephalitis attacked her brain (Photo: Jim Bennett) 
That day marked the last Tina remembers, until after she had given birth five months later. 
The care worker said: “I don’t know what happened after that except I came around months later as an encephalitis survivor and a mother.” 
Tina’s lengthy blackout started after being admitted to the local mental health hospital, St Martin’s, in September 2015 at just 21 years old, where she would spend the rest of her pregnancy learning to understand the growing bump on her stomach. 
She said: “At times I was aware I was pregnant, but I didn’t want to acknowledge it, talk about it or let people take pictures of me.” Read More 
Reduced to a shell, the family watched as a previously happy and bubbly Tina spent hours on her hospital bed, refusing to eat or drink and staring into space. 
Tina would also repeatedly call out to her grandfather, who passed away a year before. 
After nearly a week in hospital and still undiagnosed, Tina began fitting and was sent for two lumbar punctures to test fluid from her spinal cord and an MRI scan. 
She was seen by a neurologist consultant and a month later in October, diagnosed with encephalitis caused by an ovarian cyst, after an EEG brain scan showed swelling on her brain. 
Known as an ovarian teratoma, this causes neurological problems due to the presence of tissue inside the cyst which produce antibodies known as B cells. 
These cells enter the nervous system, causing damage to brain cells and in turn encephalitis. 
Tina’s condition was treated with two plasma exchanges and given anti-seizure medication and steroids. 
Incredibly, Tina, a support worker, gave birth to Ava naturally in February 2016, but has no recollection the labour. 
She said: “The birth is a total blank and the nurses tried to hand me Ava but I refused to hold her - my mum said I just freaked out. 
“I even questioned whether she was mine as I don’t remember giving birth.” 
Ava arrived prematurely and spent a month in a neonatal unit and as Tina’s memory slowly returned, frequent visits to her incubator allowed the pair to bond. 
Tina added: “I visited her every day while she was in neonatal, and started to feel more like her mother. Read More Mum's heartbreak after toddler struck by rare incurable illness leaving him paralysed 
“I always kept a baby muslin towel in my bra and Ava had one in her incubator, then I’d swap them when I visited her so she always had the scent of me with her.” 
Tina has now recovered, but has to take anti-epilepsy medication for five years and suffers minor short term memory issues. 
She says she felt the condition ‘robbed’ her of her pregnancy. 
She added: “I have strong regrets because while my family acknowledged my pregnancy, I didn’t and was not letting them take pictures of my bump. 
“Although I was not to blame for it because of the illness, I feel I was robbed of my pregnancy. 
“I never got to go out and buy baby clothes or girly things when I found out I was having a daughter.” 
Looking back at her journey to recovery, Tina says she feels like a “born survivor and fighter” after overcoming encephalitis while pregnant. 
She added: “When my family told me what I’d been through, it was like they were talking about a different person, I thought, ‘stuff like this doesn’t happen to my family’. 
“My body was having to fight not only for me, but for Ava too. I overcame this while a tiny person was growing inside me.” ENCEPHALITIS 
Wednesday marks World Encephalitis Day and landmarks across the world will be illuminated red to raise awareness. 
Niagara Falls, Trafalgar Square, Blackpool Tower and Newcastle’s Millennium Bridge will shine in support of educating more people about this life-threatening condition. 
With 6,000 sufferers in the UK each year, an average of 10% are sadly not as fortunate as Tina and lose their life to encephalitis. 
The condition occurs when an infection, sometimes originating from elsewhere in the body, spreads to the brain or when the immune system mistakenly attacks the brain. 
This causes inflammation, which if occurs suddenly or rapidly and is left untreated, can be life-threatening. 
Despite its harrowing effects, research by The Encephalitis Society shows 67% of people don’t know what the condition is and 43% have never heard of it. 
Dr Ava Easton, Chief Executive of the society, said: “In the UK, it affects more people annually than certain types of meningitis and motor neurone disease and yet remains less well known. 
“Encephalitis has a wide-spread and long-lasting impact which is why our aim is to make as many people aware of the symptoms.” 
Symptoms can include confusion or disorientation, seizures, drowsiness, changes in personality or seeing or hearing things that aren’t there. 
The NHS advises to call 999 immediately if any anyone suspects they or someone else may be suffering from encephalitis. Like us on Facebook
